snippet: European leaders have begun looking for ways, including enhanced surveillance powers, to prevent violence from militants acting virtually alone.
abstract: European leaders, in wake of Parisian terror massacre, are trying to find ways of stopping new types of terrorists comprising 'lone wolves' or small groups whose plottings are difficult to discern; smaller crews do less damage and kill less people than big attacks, but they cause great fear and propaganda that aids recruitment and financing for extremists.

byline.contributor: Katrin Bennhold and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura contributed reporting from London, and Melissa Eddy from Berlin.

lead_paragraph: European leaders have begun looking for ways, including enhanced surveillance powers, to prevent violence from militants acting virtually alone.

headline.main: Europe Focuses on Emerging Threats From Smaller Crews of Terrorists
headline.print_headline: Europe Focuses on Emerging Threats From Smaller Crews of Terrorists
